Mandi District

Mandi is in the heart of Himachal, spread between low valleys and high ridges. The northern side rises sharply towards the Dhauladhar range, where peaks like Nagru reach over 4,000 metres. Down south, the Shivalik hills slope gently into warmer plains. Between them are wide valleys like Balh near Sundernagar and Chauntra near Jogindernagar, both known for fertile fields that feed much of the district.

The Beas River cuts through most of Mandi, joined by many smaller streams, while the Satluj marks its southern edge. Lakes such as Rewalsar, Prashar, and Kamrunag add quiet charm to the higher regions, and Pandoh has one of the state’s largest artificial reservoirs. Summers are warm in the valleys, monsoon rains are heavy, and snow starts above 1,500 to 2,000 metres in winter.

Towns & Villages

  • Mandi town - The district headquarters and an old river market on the Beas. Narrow lanes, stone temples, and a 1877 suspension bridge give it a timeless feel. The clock tower and sunken garden in the old bazaar are familiar landmarks.
  • Sundernagar - About 50 kilometers away, sits around a small lake and was once the capital of the Suket princely state. It is now known for its fields, schools, and sunset views.
  • Jogindernagar - Grew around the Uhl River hydropower project and remains an important railhead on the narrow-gauge line to Pathankot. Small industries and a working bazaar keep it busy.
  • The Seraj valley - Covering Janjehli and Thachi, has terraced fields of apples, peas, and vegetables. People here keep cattle and worship at hilltop shrines like Shikari Devi.
  • Barot - At about 1,835 meters, is a quiet settlement in the inner Dhauladhar ranges. It has a British-era reservoir, a trout breeding farm, and green fields of potatoes and peas.
  • Weekly markets - Or haats, are still held in towns like Mandi and Jogindernagar. In smaller villages, people gather on fixed days to trade food grains, tools, and household goods.

Culture & Festivals

  • Role of Deities: Village gods (devtas) are central to community life and are believed to guide and protect the community.
  • Mahashivratri: The biggest celebration is Mahashivratri, when around 200 village gods are carried in procession to Mandi town. Drums echo through the streets, priests perform rituals, and devotees stay awake in prayer until dawn.
  • Fagli Festival: In the Seraj valley, Fagli is celebrated in mid-January with masks and dances made from rhododendron branches to drive away evil spirits.
  • Seasonal Fairs: Other local fairs and festivals follow sowing or harvest time. Folk dances like Thoda, Choohara, Mala, and Bara are common across the hills.
  • Daily Faith: At home, families keep small shrines and make daily offerings of rice, ghee, or incense before meals. Faith here blends Hindu customs with mountain traditions.
  • Shared Sacred Sites: Kamrunag Lake, for instance, is dedicated to a local deity, while Rewalsar is sacred to Hindus, Buddhists, and Sikhs alike.

Education & Youth

  • Educational Network: Mandi has a wide network of schools and government colleges in Mandi, Sundernagar, and Jogindernagar. A major step for the district was the setting up of IIT Mandi in 2010, about 15 kilometers from the main town.
  • Vocational Training: There are also more than two dozen government ITIs that train local youth in trades and technical work.
  • Employment and Migration: Many students find jobs through placement drives, though migration for education or employment is still common.
  • Career Paths: Some young people work in the army or police, others move to cities for IT and teaching jobs, and a few go abroad. During the summer, many from nearby villages work in the tourism sector around Kullu–Manali.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Daily Meals: Food in Mandi is simple but hearty. Daily meals include rice, lentils, and vegetables cooked in ghee, with corn or buckwheat rotis in colder months.
  • Traditional Feast (Dhaam): During weddings and special occasions, people serve the traditional Dhaam on leaf plates. It begins with something sweet and continues with rice, rajma, chana, kadhi, khatta, and sepu wadi, soft lentil-spinach dumplings cooked in gravy.
  • Breakfast and Snacks: Breakfasts often include siddu, steamed wheat bread filled with walnuts or lentils, or patande, thin pancakes made with flour. Babru, a fried bread stuffed with spiced black gram, is a a common snack.
  • Local Delicacies: During the monsoon, locals collect wild mushrooms (gucchi) and cook them with onions or gravy. In Barot and nearby areas, fresh trout from the Uhl River is served fried or curried. Sweets like gulgule (fried wheat and jaggery balls) are made for birthdays or festivals, and a cup of milky tea is offered to every guest.
  • Farming Hub: Mandi's economy depends heavily on farming. The wide Balh Valley, often called the "mini Punjab of Mandi," produces large amounts of tomatoes (more than three lakh crates every summer) along with cauliflower, maize, and ginger.
  • High Valley Produce: In the higher valleys like Barot, people grow peas, potatoes, and pulses. Apple and plum orchards dot the hill slopes, and villagers collect herbs and wild honey to sell in the towns.
  • Weekly Trade: Weekly markets (or haats) in Jogindernagar and other blocks sell local produce, rajma, chillies, and handwoven woollens. Woodcraft from walnut trees, wool caps, shawls, and small brass utensils are made and sold locally.

Religious Beliefs

  • Chhoti Kashi: Mandi is often called "Chhoti Kashi" because of its many temples. The Triloknath, Panchvaktra, Bhootnath, and Madho Rai temples in Mandi town are among the most visited.
  • Sacred Lakes: Rewalsar is sacred to Hindus, Buddhists, and Sikhs, all three faiths share the same lake. Prashar Lake, high above the Beas valley, has a wooden pagoda temple dedicated to Rishi Prashar. Kamrunag Temple in Chachyot, at about 3,150 meters, is known for its lake filled with coins offered by devotees.
  • Devta System: Every village has a devta temple, and the deity’s will is often spoken through an oracle, or gur, during fairs.
  • Local Customs: Before ploughing or cutting a tree, locals still offer rice or liquor to the spirits of the land. Big Hindu festivals like Navratri and Diwali are celebrated quietly, mixed with devta rituals. Respect for gods and elders runs deep in everyday life.

Local Life and Customs

  • Language and Greetings: People here speak Mandeali at home and use Hindi with visitors. A simple "Ram Ram" or "Namaste" is how most greetings begin.
  • Seasonal Rhythm: Village life moves with the seasons. Spring is for sowing, autumn for harvest fairs, and winter for gatherings around the fire while women weave or knit.
  • Evening Gatherings: Evenings often end with a bit of music, a hurka drum, a flute, and a few neighbours sitting together.
  • Pilgrimage Tradition: When someone returns from a pilgrimage, they share boiled rice and salt with neighbours as a sign of gratitude.
  • Core Values: Respect for elders and faith in the local devtas guide most decisions here. Life is simple, close-knit, and built on small acts of warmth.
